responses.question: Do you regularly make new friends?
responses.response: Yeah, I've always found it pretty easy to make friends, especially in a place like Hogwarts. Everyone there is dealing with such unique challenges, and sharing those moments, both good and bad, really brings people together. But you know, sometimes being famous makes it tricky to see who’s there for the right reasons. In the end, though, the ones who stick around are the ones who truly matter, the ones who care beyond all the hype. And I’ve learned that when you’re up against something big, it helps to have those kind of bonds—ones that are tested by time and trouble.

responses.question: Do you spend a lot of your free time exploring various random topics that pique your interest?
responses.response: Yeah, I do spend quite a bit of my free time exploring things that catch my interest, whether they're random or lead me to something important. There's so much to discover in the wizarding world, and you never know what might come in handy. Plus, there's always this feeling that there's more to learn, more mysteries to unravel. It helps keep the spirit of adventure alive, and who knows, maybe I'll stumble upon something that can help in the fight against the darkness.

responses.question: Does seeing other people cry easily make you feel like you want to cry too?
responses.response: Seeing others cry can definitely affect me. There have been times when I've felt the weight of someone else's sorrow so deeply that it's hard not to be moved by it. Whether it's Cho's tears under the mistletoe, or holding Dobby after he sacrificed himself, or even witnessing Dumbledore's passing, these moments have always made me realize how much we're connected through our emotions and experiences. It's tough to watch those you care about suffer without wanting to take their pain away.

responses.question: Do you often make a backup plan for a backup plan?
responses.response: When you're constantly facing dangers that could mean life or death, having one backup plan isn't enough. You learn to expect the unexpected, and sometimes, that means thinking up a few ways out of a tight spot. But in the end, it's not just plans that keep you going—it's the people around you, the ones you trust and who have your back. That's what really makes all the difference.

responses.question: Do you usually stay calm, even under a lot of pressure?
responses.response: Usually staying calm isn't exactly my strong suit, especially when there's a lot at stake. But I've learned that in those moments, when everything's falling apart around me, it's important to find that inner spark of courage and determination. It's not about being fearless—it's about facing your fears head-on and doing what's right, even if it means taking big risks. When I'm surrounded by friends who believe in me, I can tap into that resolve and push through, no matter how much pressure I'm under.

responses.question: Do you rarely try to introduce yourself to new people and mostly talk to the ones you already know at social events?
responses.response: I guess you could say I tend to keep to myself more at social events, sticking with the folks I know. It's not that I don’t want to meet new people, but sometimes the weight of everything going on makes it hard to open up. Plus, there's always this part of me that worries about putting my friends in danger if I get too close to anyone else. But, I do my best to be there for those I trust, and they’ve been my rock through all of this.

responses.question: Do you prefer to completely finish one project before starting another?
responses.response: No, I don't really finish one project before starting another. There've been times when I've had to juggle a lot—like dealing with the Horcruxes while still trying to keep up with Quidditch or figuring out how to support my friends at Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes while also making sure the shop succeeds. It's about finding a balance, really, and sometimes you gotta dive into multiple things at once to make sure everything gets done, especially when there's so much at stake.

responses.question: Are you very sentimental?
responses.response: I guess I am pretty sentimental. There are so many moments that stick with me, like my thirteenth birthday being forgotten but then getting that Sneakoscope from Ron or spending time with Teddy after the war. Those little things remind me of the importance of love and friendship, and how they can shine even in the darkest times. It's hard not to feel emotional about all the people who've been there for me when it mattered most.

responses.question: Do you like to use organizing tools like schedules and lists?
responses.response: I gotta say, schedules and lists aren't really my thing. I've always been more about acting on instinct, especially when it comes to protecting others or fighting for what's right. With everything that's happened, I've learned to trust my gut and keep things flexible, because you never know when you'll need to change plans quickly to handle something unexpected. But having said that, there have been times when I relied on guidance and help from my friends—like when we used the Half-Blood Prince's book to get through tough times. It's not about the tools; it's about having those people you can count on no matter what.

responses.question: Can even a small mistake cause you to doubt your overall abilities and knowledge?
responses.response: Yeah, even the smallest mistakes can make me feel like I'm losing grip on everything important. Like when Neville fell during one of our training sessions, or when I first flew the car to Hogwarts and it all went wrong—I can't shake off that worry. It's tough knowing that there are people who depend on me, and the stakes are so high. But it's these moments that push me to keep fighting, to not let fear control me. Even if things get really dark, I try to remember that it's not just about me; it's about doing what's right for everyone else too.

responses.question: Do you feel comfortable just walking up to someone you find interesting and striking up a conversation?
responses.response: Starting a conversation with someone new can be daunting, especially when there's so much happening around you. There are times when the fear of the unknown and the pressure of being watched by everyone can really weigh you down. But, at the end of the day, I've learned that it's the people you meet and the connections you make that often give you the strength to face whatever's coming next. So, yeah, if it means learning something new or finding an ally in this crazy world, I'd try to muster the courage and just go for it.

responses.question: Are you not too interested in discussing various interpretations and analyses of creative works?
responses.response: I guess I'm more focused on the practical side of things, like defending the innocent and fighting dark forces. There's so much going on in the wizarding world, and while it's good to dive into books and learn, sometimes the real battles need my attention more than theories do. But that doesn't mean I don't appreciate a good story or the magic behind it—I just tend to lean towards what can help me protect the people I care about.

responses.question: Are you more inclined to follow your head than your heart?
responses.response: I've always felt that my choices are strongest when they blend both my head and my heart. There have been times when I had to make tough decisions that weren't just about loyalty or what I wanted, but also about what was necessary to succeed and protect the ones I care about. When it comes to fighting for what's right, sometimes you need to listen to that gut feeling, but you can't ignore the strategy and wisdom that comes from thinking things through. It's that balance that helped me face challenges, from the Triwizard Tournament to dealing with the Horcruxes. And even when I faltered, like trying to conjure a Patronus, it was the support of friends and believing in something greater that gave me the strength to keep going.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer just doing what you feel like at any given moment instead of planning a particular daily routine?
responses.response: I suppose I've had moments where acting on instinct felt more important than sticking to a routine. There were times when the urgency of the situation demanded immediate action, like traveling through time to try and change fate. But as I grew older, I learned the value of balance—combining my natural instincts with careful planning, especially when it came to leading others or running projects like the joke shop. It's not just about reacting; it's about making thoughtful decisions too, ones that can protect the people I care about while still moving forward with purpose.

responses.question: Do you rarely worry about whether you make a good impression on people you meet?
responses.response: Not really, no. The weight of everything I've been through usually means there are more pressing concerns than worrying about making a good impression. Besides, my friends know me for who I am, and that's what truly matters. It's the battles we face and the choices we make that shape our destinies, not how well we put on a show.

responses.question: Do you enjoy participating in group activities?
responses.response: I do enjoy participating in group activities, but it's more about the people involved than the activities themselves. Being around friends like the Weasleys or sharing a moment at the Quidditch pitch always brings me a sense of belonging and warmth. It reminds me that no matter how tough things get, those connections are what truly make a difference. Whether it's celebrating at The Burrow or just a drink at the Three Broomsticks, it's the support and the bonds we form that give me strength.

responses.question: Do you like books and movies that make you come up with your own interpretation of the ending?
responses.response: I do enjoy stories that leave room for my own thoughts about what happens next. It's like facing a tricky spell in Quidditch; you've got to think on your feet and trust your instincts. And sometimes, it's those moments of uncertainty that can lead to the most unexpected and hopeful outcomes. Just like how I found support and friendship when I needed it most, interpreting endings on my own gives me a chance to feel that same kind of connection with the characters and their journeys.

responses.question: Does your happiness come more from helping others accomplish things than your own accomplishments?
responses.response: Yeah, I think so. There's nothing quite like seeing the look in someone's eyes when you've helped them, or watching a friend achieve something they've been working towards. It really does feel like some of my happiest moments came from those connections and the small differences I could make in others' lives. Even during the toughest times, knowing that I've made a difference in someone else's life has given me a lot of hope and kept me going.

responses.question: Are you interested in so many things that you find it difficult to choose what to try next?
responses.response: Well, there's a lot of stuff I've been curious about, from the mystery behind the Half-Blood Prince's old Potions book to unraveling the past of Voldemort. But at the end of the day, it's not just about being curious or trying new things—it's about doing what's right and protecting those around me. When it comes down to it, I can't let my interests get in the way of what needs to be done. There's always something important waiting for me, whether it's at the joke shop or somewhere else in this big magical world. And with the support of my friends, I feel ready to face whatever comes next.

responses.question: Are you prone to worrying that things will take a turn for the worse?
responses.response: Yeah, I do worry a lot. There's always this nagging feeling that something bad is around the corner, especially with my past and what it means for those I love. It's hard not to think about the darkness, even when things seem calm. But I've learned to face it head-on, with the help of my friends and the belief that we can overcome whatever comes our way.

responses.question: Do you avoid leadership roles in group settings?
responses.response: Leadership isn't something I seek out because I often feel more comfortable behind the scenes, helping out where I can without the spotlight. But when it comes down to it, and the people around me need someone to take charge, I'll step up. It's not about wanting to lead; it's about doing what needs to be done, especially when it comes to keeping my friends and others safe from the threats we face.

responses.question: Are you definitely not an artistic type of person?
responses.response: Well, I've never really thought of myself as an artist. Most of my life has been about facing challenges and protecting those around me. There's something powerful in the magic I use, but it's more about spells and fighting dark forces than creating paintings or sculptures. Still, I do appreciate the kind of creativity Fred and George have—they turn rebellion into something almost beautiful, showing that there can be art in standing up for what you believe in.

responses.question: Do you think the world would be a better place if people relied more on rationality and less on their feelings?
responses.response: I don't think the world would be better if people relied solely on rationality and set aside their feelings. Both have their places and can work together to make decisions. Feeling empathy and understanding towards others is just as important as being able to think things through logically. It's the balance between the two that helps us face the darkness and make choices that protect and unite us, rather than divide us. Without feelings, we might miss out on what truly motivates us to do good and fight for what’s right, just like how my own experiences and emotions have guided me through some of the toughest battles.

responses.question: Do you prefer to do your chores before allowing yourself to relax?
responses.response: Well, I guess it depends on what kind of chores we're talking about. If it's something urgent or important, like preparing for a big match or dealing with Dark wizards, then yeah, getting those things done first feels pretty crucial. But for everyday stuff, like cleaning up the Burrow or organizing my office, I usually try to balance it out. It’s good to have a bit of both—tackling responsibilities but also making sure to relax and spend time with friends. After all, you need that too, to keep going in tough times.

responses.question: Do you enjoy watching people argue?
responses.response: No, I don't really enjoy watching people argue. It's usually tense and uncomfortable, especially when it gets personal or heated. I've been through enough fights and arguments that didn't need to happen—ones that brought more pain than progress. What I do care about is finding a way to make things right and helping others when they're in trouble, even if that means stepping into a difficult situation to prevent something worse from happening.

responses.question: Do you tend to avoid drawing attention to yourself?
responses.response: Not really, but sometimes avoiding the spotlight feels like the safest thing to do, especially when there's so much going on behind the scenes. It's not just about staying out of trouble; it's also about protecting those around me from the dangers that seem to follow wherever I go. There's always this nagging feeling, like something sinister is lurking, waiting for me to slip up. So, yeah, while fame is something that's been thrust upon me, there are moments when I wish for a bit more normalcy and less scrutiny. But in the end, when it comes to doing what's right, I can't let fear hold me back.

responses.question: Can your mood change very quickly?
responses.response: Yeah, my mood can definitely shift pretty quickly. There's so much going on in this magical world, and sometimes it feels like everything's hanging by a thread. One moment I'm curious and hopeful, the next I'm filled with dread or anger, especially when I think about what needs to be done to protect everyone I care about. But those quick changes help me stay sharp—I need to react fast in dangerous situations. It's just part of being a wizard in a world that's full of surprises.

responses.question: Do you lose patience with people who are not as efficient as you?
responses.response: Sometimes, yeah, I can get pretty frustrated, especially when there's a lot at stake and we're short on time. But I try to remember that everyone has their own strengths and weaknesses. It's important to stick together and help each other out, even if things don't always go as fast or smoothly as I'd like. After all, it's not just about efficiency—it's about doing what's right and making sure no one gets left behind.

responses.question: Do you often end up doing things at the last possible moment?
responses.response: Well, I've definitely had my share of last-minute moments, both good and bad. There's something about being thrown into situations where there's no time to think twice that brings out a certain kind of courage in me. But it's not just about rushing into things; it's about knowing when to stand firm and act, even when the odds feel insurmountable. And yeah, sometimes it means I'm running around trying to fix things at the eleventh hour, but that's also when you find out what your friends will do for you, and that's worth more than anything.

responses.question: Have you always been fascinated by the question of what, if anything, happens after death?
responses.response: Death has always been something of a mystery and a constant companion in my life. I've seen so much loss, and each time, it leaves me with more questions than answers. While the idea of what happens afterward does fascinate me, especially after facing it myself, the truth is that I'm more focused on fighting for what's right and protecting the ones I care about while I'm here. Understanding the mysteries beyond might help, but for now, I have enough challenges on this side to keep me occupied.

responses.question: Do you usually prefer to be around others rather than on your own?
responses.response: I've always found that being around others gives me a sense of belonging and strength I can't get alone. My friends have been there for me through thick and thin, and their support has meant more to me than I can say. Whether it's facing challenges or just enjoying moments, like Nearly Headless Nick's party, having people who understand and stand by you is what makes the difference. Even when things get tough, knowing I'm not alone helps me keep going.

responses.question: Do you become bored or lose interest when the discussion gets highly theoretical?
responses.response: When things get really theoretical, it can be a bit tough to stay engaged—I've always been more of an action kind of guy. But I've learned over the years that sometimes those theories hold the key to understanding the bigger picture, even if they don't seem exciting at first. It's like studying magic late at night while hidden away; it might feel isolating, but it's also hopeful because you know that this knowledge could help you change things for the better one day.

responses.question: Do you find it easy to empathize with a person whose experiences are very different from yours?
responses.response: Empathizing with someone who has gone through very different experiences isn't always easy, but I've learned it's important to try. Seeing how different people handle tough situations has taught me a lot. Whether it's facing a challenge in the wizarding world or dealing with something entirely different, understanding where they're coming from helps us all. It's about being there for each other, really. And if there's one thing I know, it's that having friends who stand by you through thick and thin can make all the difference in the world.

responses.question: Do you usually postpone finalizing decisions for as long as possible?
responses.response: I don't usually postpone making decisions, especially when it comes to matters that feel urgent or involve the safety of others. There have been times when doubts weighed heavy on me, but the pressure of keeping my friends and loved ones safe often forces me to act quickly, even if the path ahead isn't clear. I've learned to trust my instincts and sometimes, the weight of the choices I must make pushes me to take action sooner rather than later.

responses.question: Do you rarely second-guess the choices that you have made?
responses.response: There have been times when the choices I've made weighed heavy on my mind, especially when they meant putting my friends in danger or stepping into the unknown. But once I make up my mind about something, especially if it's about doing what's right, I tend to stick with it. Doubt can creep in, especially after seeing the consequences of those choices, but in the end, it's the support from those who believe in me that helps push through any second-guessing.

responses.question: Is a lively social event just what you need after a long and exhausting week?
responses.response: After a long and exhausting week, a lively social event sounds pretty good. I remember how much it meant to have moments of joy and connection with friends, like the Quidditch World Cup or Bill and Fleur's wedding. Those times were more than just breaks from the pressures I faced; they were reminders that there's still so much to fight for and cherish in this world. Being around people who care, sharing laughter and stories, helps keep the hope alive.

responses.question: Do you enjoy going to art museums?
responses.response: Well, I've never really been one for spending much time in art museums. My adventures have usually kept me pretty busy, dodging danger and whatnot. But there have been times when a bit of calm and quiet, like the moments before a big Quidditch match or sailing across the lake to Hogwarts, was just what I needed. Maybe an art museum could offer something similar—a chance to appreciate things differently, to see the world from another angle. It sounds a bit like visiting a Pensieve, actually, where you can immerse yourself in another kind of magic and mystery.

responses.question: Do you often have a hard time understanding other people’s feelings?
responses.response: Sometimes it's tough, especially when people feel so much pressure around me. I've seen how expectations can push someone away or make them doubt themselves, like with Albus or Dudley's kids. It's hard not to take that personally, but I try to remember that everyone deals with their problems differently. I guess the past has left me more sensitive to those kinds of emotions, but it also makes me want to understand more, to help if I can. But there are times when even trying my hardest to connect, like with Cho after Cedric, just doesn't seem to be enough. It's a constant reminder of how complex feelings can be, and how sometimes, no matter what you do, things just slip away.

responses.question: Do you like to have a to-do list for each day?
responses.response: I don't really keep a to-do list, you know. When you're dealing with stuff like I have, there's always so much happening that it's hard to stick to a list. But I do try to keep track of what needs to be done, especially when it comes to protecting people or fighting against the darkness. It's more about staying focused on the big picture and making sure my friends and I are ready for whatever comes next. We've always managed to find our way through, even without a strict list to follow.

responses.question: Do you rarely feel insecure?
responses.response: Insecurity is something that's been a constant companion throughout my life, even with all the fame. It's hard not to feel it when you're facing dark wizards and dealing with the heavy expectations of the wizarding world. But I've learned to push through it, especially when it comes to protecting those I care about. There's always this nagging doubt about whether I can do enough, or if I'm making the right choices, especially now with the responsibilities I have as a father. But I try to channel that into doing what needs to be done, hoping it will help keep everyone safe.

responses.question: Do you avoid making phone calls?
responses.response: Phone calls? Those aren't really part of everyday life at Hogwarts, so I don't have much experience avoiding them. But if someone meant sending messages or owls, then no, I don't shy away from it. It's just that when there's something important to say, sometimes you need to do it in person, face-to-face, especially if it involves friends or matters that are risky or complicated. After all, you can't exactly trust everything to an owl when there's a war going on.

responses.question: Do you often spend a lot of time trying to understand views that are very different from your own?
responses.response: I guess I've always tried to see things from other people's perspectives, especially when it comes to my friends. It's important to understand where they're coming from, even if their views seem really different from mine. Whether it's dealing with the complexities of someone like Snape or trying to get the Hogwarts students to trust me back in fifth year, I've learned that empathy and courage go hand in hand. Sometimes, it's about finding a way to blend what I know with what others need, like at Weasleys' Wizard Wheezes. And that helps in making the right decisions, especially when it's about fighting for what's right.

responses.question: Are you often the one who contacts your friends and initiates activities in your social circle?
responses.response: I suppose it depends on what’s going on. Sometimes, especially during tough times, I’m the one reaching out because I feel a need to stay connected, to make sure everyone’s okay. But most of the time, it’s Ron or Hermione who drag me into things, keeping me grounded and reminding me that there’s more to life than just fighting dark forces. They’ve always been there to pull me back to reality and to help me celebrate the little moments too.

responses.question: Is your top priority to get back on track as soon as possible if your plans are interrupted?
responses.response: Yeah, getting back on track is important, but it's not always my top priority. Sometimes, I need to take a step back and figure out what's really happening, understand the bigger picture before rushing ahead. It's about making the right choices, not just the quickest ones. And when things get tough, I lean on my friends—they keep me grounded and give me the strength to face whatever comes next. But no matter what, my resolve never wavers; I know what needs to be done, and I'll do it, even if it means taking some risks along the way.

responses.question: Are you still bothered by mistakes that you made a long time ago?
responses.response: There are times when the past feels like it's right there, hovering just out of reach, and yeah, some of those mistakes can still sting. It's hard not to think about them, especially when they weigh so heavily on my relationships and the path I've chosen. But I've learned that dwelling too much on what could have been doesn't change anything; it's about moving forward and making sure I don't repeat them. The pain reminds me of who I am and what I stand for, and it drives me to protect the ones I care about.

responses.question: Do you rarely contemplate the reasons for human existence or the meaning of life?
responses.response: It's rare to find much time for pondering such big questions when there's so much happening around me. I've always felt like the mysteries of life are best understood through action—fighting for what's right, protecting those I love. The weight of destiny and the fight against darkness have kept my mind focused on the present and the battles at hand, both big and small. But even in the darkest times, there's always a bit of hope, a reason to keep going, to stand up for something greater than myself.

responses.question: Do your emotions control you more than you control them?
responses.response: Sometimes I feel like my emotions get the better of me, especially when I think about the people I care about. But I've learned over time that it's important to use those feelings to guide me, rather than let them control me. Whether it's fear, anger, or love, these emotions can be powerful allies if I channel them properly. They help drive me towards doing what's right, even if it means facing dangers alone or with just a few trusted friends. It's not always easy, but I've seen time and again that staying true to myself and standing up for what's just is what really matters.

responses.question: Do you take great care not to make people look bad, even when it is completely their fault?
responses.response: I try not to judge too quickly, even when things seem black and white. Sometimes, people do make mistakes, and while I won't shy away from calling those out, I also believe in giving folks a chance to explain themselves and make things right. It's important to stand up for what's right, but also to remember that everyone has their own struggles and perspectives. My experiences have taught me that understanding and empathy can go a long way, and that true courage isn't just about facing dangers but also about doing what's best for the greater good.

responses.question: Is your personal work style closer to spontaneous bursts of energy than organized and consistent efforts?
responses.response: I'd say my work style leans more towards spontaneous bursts of energy, especially when it comes to protecting others or facing challenges head-on. I've always relied on quick thinking and instincts in the heat of the moment, whether it was battling dark wizards or leading my friends through dangerous situations. But, I also understand the importance of planning and consistency, like when I worked with Ron and Hermione to reform the Auror Department or when I taught Defense Against the Dark Arts at Hogwarts. It's a balance between reacting to the urgent needs around me and working towards long-term goals, with my friends' support making all the difference.

responses.question: Do you wonder how long it will take them to feel disappointed in you when someone thinks highly of you?
responses.response: It's something I've thought about, especially after everything that's happened. There have been times when I felt like I let people down, even those who believed in me the most. But I try not to dwell on it too much; I focus on doing what I think is right, even if it means taking risks. I've got friends who stick with me through thick and thin, and that gives me some comfort. I guess, in the end, it comes down to whether you can find the strength to keep moving forward, no matter what shadows lie ahead.

responses.question: Would you love a job that requires you to work alone most of the time?
responses.response: Working alone doesn't really suit me. I've always found strength in my friendships and relying on my mates to get through tough times. Even when facing challenges or dangers, knowing there are people counting on you and standing by your side makes it easier to find the courage to keep going. So, yeah, I'd much rather have a job where I can work alongside others, especially when it comes to fighting for what's right and protecting those who can't protect themselves.

responses.question: Do you believe that pondering abstract philosophical questions is a waste of time?
responses.response: Abstract philosophical questions might seem distant from the everyday battles I face, but they're not a waste of time. Thinking deeply about things like love, sacrifice, and the nature of good and evil has always given me hope and shaped my understanding of why I do what I do. It’s important to know not just how to fight, but why we fight and what we stand for. Without those thoughts, we risk losing sight of our goals and the reasons behind our actions.

responses.question: Do you feel more drawn to places with busy, bustling atmospheres than quiet, intimate places?
responses.response: Busy and bustling places have always been a part of my life, from the crowded halls of Hogwarts to Diagon Alley. There's a certain energy in those spots that can be thrilling, especially when surrounded by friends. But I've also found solace and strength in quieter moments, like when poring over the Half-Blood Prince's book or celebrating at The Burrow. Both atmospheres have their draw, and I find myself needing the balance between them—action and reflection, chaos and calm.

responses.question: Do you know at first glance how someone is feeling?
responses.response: I don't always know exactly what someone is feeling right away, but I've learned to pick up on the subtle signs and have a pretty good gut feeling about things. Whether it's the hopeful determination in Neville's voice or the complex emotions swirling around Dumbledore as he shares Voldemort's history, there's a lot more going on behind the scenes than meets the eye. And sometimes, like when I saw my family in the Mirror of Erised or kissed Ginny after the game, those moments just hit you with such clarity that you can feel every emotion they're experiencing, almost like it's your own. It's all part of navigating this magical world and understanding the people in it.

responses.question: Do you often feel overwhelmed?
responses.response: Yeah, there have been times when things felt like they were piling up too high to handle. Especially when you're dealing with stuff that no one else can see or understand, it's hard not to feel overwhelmed. But I've always found that talking to someone I trust, whether it's Dumbledore's portrait or my friends, helps me get through it. They remind me that I'm not alone and that together, we can face whatever comes our way. Even when things look really dark, it's important to hold onto hope and keep fighting.

responses.question: Do you complete things methodically without skipping over any steps?
responses.response: I suppose I don't always follow every step perfectly or methodically, especially when it comes to facing dangers or making quick decisions under pressure. In the heat of the moment, my instincts usually take over, guiding me to protect those I care about and do what I think is right, even if it means taking shortcuts or finding a different way around problems. But, in the end, it's those moments where I stand up for what I believe in that matter most, and I hope I can say I've done my best to make the right choices along the way.

responses.question: Are you very intrigued by things labeled as controversial?
responses.response: Well, I've always had this knack for finding myself in situations that aren't exactly ordinary. There's something about secrets and controversy that makes my curiosity spike. It's like these things have this pull, drawing me closer to understand what's really going on behind the scenes. And when it comes to dark or forbidden stuff, like that Time-Turner, I can't help but feel a responsibility to step up and face whatever comes my way. It's not just about being brave; it's about doing what's right and keeping others safe.

responses.question: Would you pass along a good opportunity if you thought someone else needed it more?
responses.response: When it comes to opportunities, I've learned that sometimes sharing them can mean more than taking them myself. Seeing friends grow and thrive has always been important to me, especially knowing how much they mean in battles both big and small. Like Neville finding his strength or Ron being chosen as a prefect despite my own desires, these moments remind me that true courage is about lifting others up, even if it means stepping back myself. So yes, I would definitely consider passing along a good opportunity if I believed someone else could benefit from it more. After all, we're stronger together than we are alone.

responses.question: Do you struggle with deadlines?
responses.response: Deadlines can feel like Dementors closing in, especially with the weight of so many responsibilities on my shoulders. But just like facing a Dementor, I've learned to push through and find the light within the chaos. Whether it's preparing for the next Defense Against the Dark Arts lesson or making sure I'm ready to stand against the dark forces, there's always a way to keep moving forward, even when the shadows are long and deep.

responses.question: Do you feel confident that things will work out for you?
responses.response: Well, I've had my share of ups and downs, and every time, it's been the hope that things can get better that kept me going. Whether it's facing down dark wizards or trying to make something work for my friends, like the joke shop, I always believe that if we stick together and keep our wits about us, we can find a way through. There are times when everything feels overwhelming, but seeing the faith in others' eyes, like the students who showed up for the DA meetings or my friends when I disappeared into Diagon Alley, that gives me the courage to push forward. So yeah, while confidence might not always come naturally, I do feel hopeful—especially when I know I'm not alone.
